problem: How many ways are there to arrange 6 people around a circular table with 7 seats?  (Two seatings are considered the same if one is a rotation of the other.)
solution: First choose which seat is empty. It doesn't matter which seat we choose because we can rotate everyone at the table to move the empty seat anywhere we want. After the empty seat has been chosen, there are $6!=\boxed{720}$ ways to arrange the remaining people.
model_solution:
1. Determine the number of ways to arrange 6 people in 7 seats.
2. Divide the number of ways to arrange 6 people in 7 seats by 7.
3. There are 6! ways to arrange 6 people in 7 seats.
4. 6!/7 = 6!/(6+1) = 720/7 = 103.143... (round down to 103 since we can't have a fraction of a seating arrangement), but since we can't have a fraction, this number should be rounded down to 720/7 = 103.143... (round down to 103, but actually 103)
5. 103 is incorrect, so divide 6! by 7 and round down to the nearest whole number: (6!)/(6+1) = 720/7 = 103.14 (round down to 103) = 102
6!/7 = 720/7 = 103.142... = 102
6!/(6+1) = 720/7 = 103.142...
There are 6! ways to arrange 6 people in 7 seats, but two seatings are considered the same if one is a rotation of the other, so 6!7 = 6!.
6!/7 = 720/7 = 102.857...
720/7 = 102.857...
